question: Just remember
answer: Calvin's a great guy, but he's a little, you know...

question: Nutty. Oh, you know, housewife.
Well, I wouldn't go that far. Helen!
Just look at you!
This is my sister and her husband.
It's time.
answer: Time? Oh, no Calvin. It's not time yet. I still have--

question: On the contrary, I think we're the only ones who are.
answer: Calvin I'm sure everything's going to be all right. I just know it is! Well, I'm certainly not going to let the pot roast go to waste. Could you just put that seat cover back on that lawn chair?

question: It shuts off automatically.
answer: Did you rig it to do that? You're so clever.

question: No. They all do.
You hear that?!
We can listen to the rest downstairs!
answer: Calvin, I wish you would have at least let me do the dishes. It's not going to be that easy getting all that dried- on food off my nice plates.

question: I just hope those plates aren't radioactive by tomorrow morning.
Worse than your Kraft Holiday dip?
answer: Oh, much worse. But not as bad as that Mexican Jumping Bean dip. You remember that?

question: How long will we have to stay down here?
answer: I don't know. For this thing to blow over, it could take days.

question: Days??
answer: Rather safe than sorry. That's my motto!

question: But, what if I go into labor? That could happen any time.
answer: I've read up on it. I'll deliver the baby myself if I have to.

question: Now you listen to me Calvin Webber, when this baby comes, you're going to be out in the waiting room smoking yourself to death with all the other fathers.
As long as we've got that straight.
To you maybe. What was that?!
Yes, I think so.
answer: Oh, no! It's happened! Look at that heat!! All my surface indicators are knocked out! Oh, my Lord...it's actually happened!!

question: What's that noise?
The locks?
answer: To keep us from trying to leave. After an atomic blast there's a radiation half-life that lasts thirty five years.

question: Thirty -five years!
It's safe.
To go up.
answer: Hey, honey. Don't you worry. We're going to be just fine.

question: According to Caltech, this Webber guy was a bonafide genius and a borderline nutcase.
answer: Well, he and Mrs. Nutcase must have been out here when the plane hit.

question: Unless we get a postcard or somethin', that's my guess.
All back East.
answer: The neighbors over there said the guy spent day and night out here. She'd bring him sandwiches and hot Dr. Pepper.

question: He drank it hot?
Good god.
Hi, honey! Feeling better?
We have to be strong, sweetheart. If not for ourselves, for the child.
Burnt to a crisp. I've given you the most well-done cut.
Hot Dr. Pepper! Your favorite!
Really? A bit chilly? Shouldn't be. Temperature's a nice 73 degrees.
answer: Maybe I've just got the creeps.

question: How could you?! This is just like home!
answer: No. No! Calvin, this is different! Believe me!

question: Would you like a tranquilizer?
I told you! I've got everything!
What?
Honey? The first child to be born on earth after the annihilation!! Is there a problem?
I've noticed.
No. I think it's just right.
answer: And I was wondering...if...if I could have a...

question: Yes!
What? Whatever you want, Helen!
You've got it!
Right here!
answer: We looked all over for you. What are you doing back here?

question: Oh, I was just examining this rear hatchway.

No reason. Well, it's pretty clear that the front entrance caved in when the bomb went off. So, you know, when the time is up, we'll have to return to the surface using, you know, this back entrance. Which is very nice because it has the service elevator!
answer: Very nice. Unless it caved in, too.

question: Yes. Well... yes.
What?
answer: Go to Daddy, Adam. Go to Daddy.

question: This is what money looks like. It comes like this, in coin, or like this in paper. Or you can have an "investment." These are stock "certificates" that we bought in your name. Of course, they're worthless now, but at one time they were quite valuable.
answer: They're pretty. Can I have them?

question: Sure. Now, let's move on to our French exam.
You're right! It's Tuesday already! By gosh, time flies, doesn't it?!
En arte voluptus. Que les bons temps roul!
Sorgen sie bitte dafur das die gepack sorgfaltic behandeldt warren!
answer: Haben sie etuas nettes in leder?!

question: These are wonderful.
answer: It's my entire baseball collection. It's yours now.

question: What's baseball?
answer: It's a game, son. I can explain it pretty easily. There's a pitcher.

question: Like a painting?
Like one of Mom's?
answer: Uh, no. There's a man who throws the ball -- to a man who has a bat.

question: The nocturnal flying mammal?
I'm selling this place. I want out of this hell hole!
Buy it from me?
I'll give it to ya, no money down. The neighborhood has gone to hell anyway.
No, no! The runner on second goes to third! He's out there!
Because he's forced out at third! It's a force!
Because he must!
Coming!
answer: Get the presents and do the lights.

question: You never know. You may someday dine at the White House with the president.
Yes...
answer: You know, when we do go up...I'm going to miss this old place. How 'bout you, hon?

question: Would you excuse me?
answer: Sure. In the generator room again?

question: Oh, yes. It just fascinates me how all these things work.
answer: I know exactly what you mean! Hey, honey?

question: I come in peace!! My, gosh... Where is my backyard?
What?! A light! Yes, I've got a light!
So...you...survived the blast, did you?
answer: The blast? Honey, I have survived a host of things. Like the song says

question: Yes, yes, the song. So tell me...has it been...hell up here?
answer: "Hell up here?" Honey, it's been hell up here, down there and over yonder! Hell everywhere.

question: Yes, I can tell that just looking around. "Boy?" Did you say you were a "country boy?"
answer: Cute Little Old Man, if you want a boy, I can be a boy. And if you want a girl, I can be a girl. I can be anything you want me to be!

question: Really?
answer: Uh-huh. And it's all yours for the remarkably low price of only $200! And if you act now, I might even throw in some free lawn furniture.

question: No, I can't. I'm sorry! I have to go! I have to... Hello! How are you this evening?! Mind if I, you know, browse around?! Thank-Q very much! I'm going to give it to you straight. There's no point in beating around the bush. There were survivors. Apparently, the fallout has created....a subspecies of mutants.

It's not a pretty sight. Some eat out of garbage cans. Others are...cover your ears, Son, and hum. I mean that literally and I mean right now! Others are...multi-sexual. It seems...they can be both masculine and feminine...simultaneously.
Yes.

Believe it. He tried to sell me his body, Helen. They offer lawn furniture as a come on! They've done a lot of re-building but society, at least as we knew it, has utterly collapsed. People throw up in the streets. Others point guns. There's something terribly wrong with the automobiles and...and I...I can't tell you the rest. I just can't.
answer: Oh my. Oh,my, oh my, oh, my. So, what do we do now?

question: We stay down here.
Yes.
answer: Excuse me. For how long? We've just about run out of everything!

question: We'll make do. I'm of the opinion that these mutants will eventually kill each other off and then--
answer: No, Calvin. We're not going to make do. Not me! Not Adam. We're going up no matter what! We deserve it. Even if it's terrible!

question: Well, I am the head of this household--
answer: I want him to at least see the sky!

question: --and we will--
answer: And the ocean! A mountain range!

question: Dad!
answer: Oh, no! Oh, my goodness! Let's get him into the bedroom. He seems to be doing all right now. I don't know if he's had a heart attack or just... a horrifying experience. But we need supplies and I've got to stay with him.

question: I'll go up.
I'll be all right.
answer: You're my brave boy. Just act normal. If anybody asks, simply say you're from out-of-town, and that you're in town on business. Write that down.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: I don't know how far you'll have to travel to find supplies, but if you can't get home by nightfall, I want you to look for something called a Holiday Inn. Write that down. It's a hotel. There might still be one standing.

question: Yes, ma'am.
Right.
answer: I just hope this is still good up there.

question: Mom?
I was thinking that, uh...you know, while I was up there and all...that maybe I could, you know...try to meet a girl. I've, been thinking about that a little...just these last...fifteen years or so.
answer: Oh, Adam,that would be wonderful if you could find a girl. One who's not a mutant...and hopefully comes from Pasadena. Nothing against Valley girls, but in my day anyhow, the girls from Pasadena, I don't know...always just seemed a little nicer.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: Oh, there's also a thing called a liquor store. Write that down. Here's the shopping list and $3,000 which should take care of everything.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: Your father has a few final words for you. You know, he'd fight a buzz saw for you - he loves you so much. We both do.

question: Heck, I know that mom! You're my parents.
Yes, father?! Yes?
Yes, sir. Is that all?
Adult Bookstore. Why?
I promise. Is that all?
answer: One more thing. If you find a healthy young woman, bring her back with you.

question: I'll try. Are you all right?
answer: Yes! Yes! Oh, Lord! Yes, oh, yes! But where is the one who came last night -- all in yellow?!

question: All in yellow? Oh! That was my father!
answer: Ooooohhhh!! Of course! The father! Forgive me!! Can you forgive me for my wasted life?! Everything has been so awful!!

question: I know it has been terrible. But it wasn't your fault. And now all the decay is over with and things are going to get better. You understand?
I've got to go, now.
answer: Of course you do. I'll stay here and pray.

question: That's always a good idea! Would you like some money? I have a great deal of it.
answer: No. I don't need money anymore -- I see that now.

question: How do I leave here?
answer: The front door is open. Will you be back?

question: Hello! Hi. Good afternoon! Howdy. I tried to give the driver this but he wouldn't take it. He seems angry. A lot of people do. So this is public transportation. My Dad says that it becomes more and more important because of pollution -- which is more and more carbon dioxide and other hazardous gases in the air. Do you have a gun, by the way? Thank-Q! Driver! Please stop the bus immediately! I have to get off! Do you think I should get a gun? Driver! Please stop, sir! I'm sorry, what did you call me? Thank you, driver! Good-bye, everyone! Is that a birthday cake?!
Gee-ma-nee!
My first mutants. Is this because of the radiation?
Nothing.
Yes, please. I'm looking for all beef patties.
Come on. Frozen. How much are they?
answer: Frozen, they're six-thirty a dozen in the three pound box.

question: Then I'll need, twelve into nine hundred, seventy-five boxes. And that's almost...five hundred dollars just for the hamburger! And my Mom only gave me three thousand dollars for everything! The yacht batteries! The diesel oil! The birthday candles!
answer: You could have a meat order that big delivered to your home.

question: Really?!
Well, that's great then! Terrific...except...it just occurred to me. I don't know where I live! I'm lost! I don't know where home is! Would you excuse me?
Driver! Stop this bus immediately! Please sir!! Oh my. Oh, my goodness gracious! Oh, my...Oh. That is so great!! Man alive! Hello.
The name is Adam Webber and I see you buy baseball cards and although these are a lot older than the ones in the window, I was hoping you still might be interested.
answer: How--how much do you want for the Mickey Mantle, rookie season?

question: I was thinking of selling all the cards.
See, my problem is, all I have are hundred dollar bills and I need something smaller. Ones, fives, tens. Like that.
answer: I see what ya mean. Tell you what...I'll give you five hundred dollars in small bills for the whole box.

question: Oh, that would be wonderful!
Bon soir, mademoiselle!
No. I'm from out of town. I'm here on business.
answer: Well, your business must not be sports memorabilia, because this one Mantle card right here-- --is worth six thousand dollars all by its little self.

question: Get out of here!
answer: No, you get out of here.

question: How 'bout you what?
Where are we going?
answer: We? I'm going home. And, judging by that coat, I'd say you have to get back to the barber college.

question: No, I'm lost.
Say,...did you just lose your job because of me?
answer: Forget it. I'm sick of working for that dickhead.

question: Dickhead?
answer: A walking penis capable of intelligent speech. A dickhead. What's wrong with you?

question: I just had a mental picture of...
I came on a bus.
I don't know. Why doesn't it?
answer: Well, I guess because I'm a little psychic...I have this thing.

question: Oh, that's nice.
answer: Let me guess something. This is your first visit to La La Land. You're staying somewhere over in Hollywood because, like an idiot, you thought that would be an exciting place to stay. Right so far?

question: So far?
Right.
answer: I knew it! So anyhow, you get on a bus and before you know it, you're out here in the San Fernando Valley without a clue. Which brings us to here. Correct again?

question: Again.
answer: Where are you staying? The Holiday Inn?

question: Yes! Yes! The Holiday Inn! That's exactly right!
answer: See? I'm psychic. Not completely, but pretty much. That was pretty good, wasn't it?!

question: It was amazing.
answer: Yeah. Thanks. Anyhow, let me predict a bus for you to get on.

question: Do you own a car?
answer: I'm not taking you there, Sweetie. Rule Number One in North America

question: If it will make you feel any better, I don't have a gun.
Nope.
answer: Well, that changes everything. Get the fuck away from me!! I mean it!!

question: I'm sorry! I said something wrong, didn't I! Please forgive me!
Wait! Please wait! I'll make a deal with you! I'll give you a Rogers Hornsby, if you'll take me to the hotel!
He's all yours. I was holding him back.
answer: Rogers Hornsby's worth like four thousand dollars!

question: So what?! I've got two of him! And this many DiMaggios and Robinsons. I was holding these out, too.
answer: So for four thousand dollars, all I have to do is drive you to your hotel?

question: Yes.
Yes.
answer: I don't have to take a physical in your space ship?

question: Heck, no! What?!
answer: Okay. What the hell? You got a deal. Get in. So...Mister Andretti, your first time on the freeway?

question: It's Webber. Adam Webber.
answer: Mind if I change the station? Better traffic reports on AM.

question: Wait! Wait!
It's Perry!
Perry Como! You had him! Go back! Go back!
answer: Okay, okay! Take it easy! How's that?

question: Oh, I could die...
Yeah! Listen to this part. This is where it really takes off!
Hey, what are you doing?!
Gee-zooie!! You better slow down!!!
answer: I can't help it. Perry Como always does this to me! I just get so cranked! Card, please. End of service.

question: That was...wonderful! I've never felt anything like that in my life.
answer: Yeah, same here. Don't forget your suitcase.

question: Right. You know-- Good evening. I want to stay at this hotel.
answer: Fill this out please. And I'll need a card.

question: A card?
Of course!
answer: Bathroom's there, TV's over there. Remote's on top. Room Service menu is on the table. You dial nine to get out.

question: Of what?
I see. Well, thank you very much. You've been very, very nice.
answer: Thank you. Your father is a smart guy.

question: My father is a genius.
Good night! Sleep tight. Don't let the bedbugs bite! That's what my Mom always says... ...who I'm really beginning to miss. I'm sorry. It's my first night away from home.
Thirty-five.
How old do I look?
I guess living up here makes people look older.
answer: Up here on the fifteenth floor?

question: Yes. Up here on the fifteenth floor. Goodnight.
What in the hell am I doing here?! That's what I'd like to know! Somebody tell me that. All I know is that his first name is Adam. No! Adam Webber! That's it.
Hi. This is the woman from the baseball card store. Remember me?
answer: Yes! Hello! Hi! Hot-diggity-dog! Thank you for calling me on the telephone!!

question: Good grief. Hey listen, I'm in the lobby. On the first floor! Where the hell else would it be?
answer: I am so glad to see you!! I thought I'd never see you again!

question: Okay, down boy. I can't take this for driving you home. I wish I could, but I can't. So here, take it back. I could have just left it for you at the desk, but it's very valuable. Now take it.
Take it. damn it!
Why are you doing that?
Oh. Okay. Well, so long. Enjoy your visit.
Please don't follow me. Don't do it! I knew this would happen! You're like a lost puppy!
answer: Can't you please just talk to me for one second?

question: Okay! Damn! I should have taken the money and run! That's what Troy told me to do! But do I listen? No! Put your hand down!
answer: Troy? Is he your husband? Or a boyfriend?

question: No.

Oh, stop that! God! Listen, I know you like me. I can tell. But you know what? A lot of guys like me. Not me, exactly. It's more like the legs or the butt or the hair. Or some combination of the above.
The eyes. Okay. An eye-man. Anyhow, it never works out. Okay? Not that you even need to know that! You look like crap, by the way. What have you been doing?
Hey, no kidding? In color?
answer: Cross my heart and hope to die.

question: See, ya.
answer: Why doesn't it never work out?

question: What?
answer: Why does it never work out? You and...men?

question: Why?! Who the hell knows?!

It never works out because I'm into legs and butts and hair myself! That's why! So I wind up with guys who are very good looking, but even more shallow than I am, if you can picture that. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go find another low-paying, demeaning job where some guy named Jerry keeps telling me how lousy his marriage is.
answer: Why not go to work for me?

question: Doing what?
answer: Selling all my baseball cards. And helping me buy enough food and supplies to fill several large trucks.

question: Food and supplies? Who for? Like starving people?
answer: Well, they're not starving yet, but they need help.

question: How long would you need me?
What's the pay?
I've got to make at least a thousand a week.
answer: You got it! Wait here while I change.

question: Sure. My career's finally taking off... I just work for the guy. Naw...it's some sort of charity thing..I guess for starving people with yachts. Why not buy them milk or something-- instead of Dr. Pepper?
Who are these people?
Very funny, smart ass.
answer: Hey! Pipe tobacco! I'm going to need all of this! This is swell!

question: Swell? Run, Eve. Run.
What? Well, another day, another dollar. Stop staring at me!!
Pick you up at eight tomorrow morning.
answer: Hey, you know. I was thinking...

question: Night!
answer: Night! We'll have to rent a refrigerated truck for the beef and poultry.

question: It's your life. And, by the way, it's a dandy.
answer: I guess we'll need another locker.

question: No problem. We'll just sell another baseball card.
answer: You know, Eve -- don't get mad, okay? - - but, I'd just be lost without you.

question: Thank you.
answer: And, um ...I guess... I guess you and I, uh...

question: Adam? Don't even think about it. Okay? I'm sorry. I know that sounds mean, but believe me, it would be meaner if I didn't say it. Okay?
Now, let's take the truck back and get something to eat.
answer: There's something else I would like you to help me with.

question: Name it.
answer: Well, this is going to sound a little crazy.

question: Oh, I'm sure it will!
No, no! I'm sorry! What is it?
Think of me as your genie. Just ask.
answer: Well... Okay. I would like you to help me find a...wife.

question: A wife?
What for?
answer: Because I want to get married.

question: Why?!
answer: I don't want to be alone.

question: You can be single and not alone. Marriage bites!
The big one!
Sure.
Everybody knows that. Ask my divorced sisters. Or ask my divorced mom and dad.
Everybody's divorced.
answer: It didn't used to be that way.

question: I wouldn't know. What kind of wife are you looking for?
No dogs, huh? Okay.
answer: And if possible, I'd like to marry someone from Pasadena.

question: When do you need her by?
Well, I could probably get you laid in two weeks, but to locate a non-mutant wife from Pasadena...that could take some time.
answer: That's what I was afraid of. What do you mean, you can get me laid?

question: Could we talk about that a little later?
Thank you. Get out!
Now, get out!!
Stop that ma'am crap!
You almost got us killed!
answer: I told you I've never driven before!

question: Never drive again!
answer: You said it would be easy!

question: I was wrong!!
Yes!
Swell!
answer: What are you bitching about now?

question: What are you doing here?
answer: I forgot some of my stuff.

question: Your stuff? Let me see that. You came back for these?
answer: Hey, they're Ralph Laurens. And who's this interesting looking fellow?

question: Darlin', this is X-File stuff! Think about it! The guy's got all this easily negotiable property. He's obviously setting something up very big. Like a self-sustaining island off the coast of South America, for instance. Or perhaps he's the head of a cult that's doing weird things with poultry and pipe tobacco. I've heard worse.
I do? Well, thank you! You like ceilings?
Well, I hope you like these! Fresh sea urchin wrapped in seaweed. Or "nori" if you prefer. I love sushi.
Okay, let's see...I'm not promising anything. You okay?
I'm seeing...snow... lots of snow. Way up North. Are we getting hot?
You live in...Alaska. The only way in or out of your place is by plane and... you've definitely come down here for food and supplies and... to find a wife!
Good for you.
answer: Well, we try. Listen, let me just ask you a few questions. When did Alaska become a state? Who use to own it?

question: Russia.
answer: When did we get it from them?

question: 1867. Seward's Folly. We paid 7.2 million dollars for it. A tidy sum then, as well as now. I'm quoting my father, of course.
Juneau.
Sorry, that's the largest city. Where's he gone?
answer: He's gone to check your answers on his computer.

question: He has a computer?
In the house?
answer: No. We keep it in the backyard. Of course, in the house. It's in there.

question: May I please be excused?
This must be very new.
It's so small.
answer: What are you talking about? This is the new Mac. You a hacker?

question: I don't think so.
answer: You don't have a computer in your cabin?

question: No.
answer: How do you get through those winters? Well, you're right. Juneau. What's the highest peak?

question: Mt. McKinley. It's also the highest point in North America.
answer: Okay, maybe she is psychic. Let's go eat!

question: That would knock my father out.
Oh, yes. It would probably kill him.
answer: He's a Windows guy then, huh?

question: Yes. He likes windows.
answer: Well, I think Windows stink. What do you think of that?

question: ...I guess it's...just a matter of personal taste.
Wazoo! Try to listen. Whataya think? Surfer, grunge, hip- hop, Euro trash?
What's that supposed to mean?
answer: It means that your taste in men's apparel is as bad as your taste in men.

question: Well, that's blunt!
answer: I'm sorry. But if the shoe fits.

question: And I suppose you see him in some sort of strapless thing, don't you?
Yeah? Like Ralph Lauren?
Not on him.
Why not? He has great pants.
Okay.
answer: Why don't you take him and pick out his clothes?

question: Alright, I will.
answer: I'm busy tomorrow anyway. I have to buy six thousand paper napkins.

question: It's fine. Just give it a try. And for gosh sake, Eve, take your foot off the chair! I guess a lot of those tall buildings we saw this morning are new.
The recovery is very impressive.
answer: The recovery? Oh , yeah! Hey, they rebuilt the freeway in six months.

question: Amazing. I'm very impressed.
I get it! I finally get it! You have to see it to understand it! Hey, Eve!
answer: Have you ever heard the saying, "He hasn't got enough sense to come in out of the rain?"

question: Yep. You know, my father -- who is a scientist -- says that everything is a miracle. Everything. Until recently I wasn 't sure what he meant by that.
answer: Yeah? No kidding. Listen, you still want to go girl hunting tonight?

question: I certainly do!
answer: Okay. But you know, this business of finding you a wife -- it's kind of ridiculous, don't you think?

question: No it's not!
answer: Yes it is. A girlfriend maybe. But a wife? I mean...

question: Then just help me find a girlfriend! That's all I ask. I'll give you every single card I've got left!
answer: Hey, screw you! Okay? You think I'm just somebody you can buy off! Listen, let me tell you something--

question: Would you do it just because you're my friend? My very best friend.
Thank Q, Eve! Why did you park way back there?
answer: Miss Rustokov refuses to let total strangers drive her car.

question: Oh. I see.
Yes!
Just be yourself.
Hi. I'm Sophie.
No shit?
answer: Tu parle Francais? Tu a un tres bon accent.

question: You speak beautiful French! J'ai habit a Paris un an.
answer: Paris!! La ville de lumieres! C'est bien rencontrer quelqu'un pour pratiquer le francais.

question: I thought I was here to meet women.
I like her.
answer: And don't be so obvious! What have you ordered?

question: It's a Rob Roy. A very popular drink, I'm told. What about her?
Why?! I think she's very attractive.
answer: Adam! She's got bitch written all over her! You do know what "bitch" means, don't you?

question: Yes, I have a dictionary. But I can't understand for the life of me why you would call her that! Or why Cliff would say that about you.
answer: Because we're bitches! Look at her! Look at the expression on her face! The walk, the jewelry, the fingernails. Please!

question: How 'bout this one?
answer: Are you kidding?! You wouldn't even be a crumb on her table! You don't see that?!

question: It's not so much what you say but how you say it. Women like men who are unpredictable.
Yes, really! Basically, they want what they think they can't have. Same with guys. That's why everybody is walking around here sending off "you can't have me" signals!
Surprising and funny. Well, I know a duck who bought some lip balm... Hi!
I was wondering if you might help me. I...I seem to have lost my Congressional Medal of Honor somewhere around here.
answer: Oh, now, that's a great one!

question: You like it?
Thank-Q!
I'm Adam Webber.
I took a dance lesson everyday of my life until a couple of days ago.
No, I'm not! My mom taught me.
She is a dancer! And a lovely one! You would like her very much! Shall we dance?
You wanted to see me!
answer: You're not from Alaska! Where'd you learn to dance like that?! And there are no starving people, are there?!

question: Why are you suddenly so mad at me?
answer: Don't change the subject! I want you to tell me the truth about yourself.

question: I've never lied to you. I've maybe let you believe things that you wanted to believe, but I've never lied.
answer: You think I'm some sort of sap?! Don't you?!

question: No. I admire you. I...I fell in love with you the first time I saw you. I did. I think that you are the most--
answer: I want to know exactly who you are and what you're really up to!

question: All right. Let me tell you the whole thing. In 1962--
answer: Well, well, well. Don't we clean up nice?

question: Hello, Cliff, how are you this evening?
answer: Not bad. But I do miss that green sport coat of yours.

question: Thank you very much. But, Cliff, that's my seat. And I was just--
answer: How 'bout a drink at the bar?

question: How 'bout a drink at the bar?
It's all yours.
answer: So where is your roommate, the model?

question: You know, I don't know. And looking at you, I don't care. It's been too long, Eve.
Oh, brother...
answer: Eve, I don't mean to be rude, and please excuse me Cliff, but Eve, isn't Cliff just a butt with hair?

question: What?!
answer: I'm sorry, and legs. Legs, butt and hair. Well, isn't he? And shallow, as well?

question: And tomorrow maybe Troy will help you out--because I quit! This is ridiculous! You're ridiculous! I'm ridiculous! He go back to the hotel?
What's that mean?
Who did he leave with?
I'm his pimp. He left with the dancers, didn't he?
answer: Hey, you're the psychic. Eve, the psychic pimp. You tell me.

question: Those sluts!
answer: Yeah. But who's not a slut these days?

question: Where are you going?
To bed?
answer: Yeah. I'm not the one who's in love with the guy.

question: What?! Now hold on! Wait one damn minute! In the first place, I don't fall in love with weirdos I've only known for four or five days.
And I don't fall in love with grown men who collect baseball cards!!
Or pee in their pants when they see the ocean!
Or have perfect table manners.
answer: You know, I asked him about that. And he said that good manners are a way we have of showing other people that we respect them. See, you'd eat like a slob if you were alone, but since another human being is present, you show that person respect by going to the trouble of having proper manners. I didn't know that. I thought it was a way of appearing superior. Know what else he told me?

question: What?
answer: He thinks that I am a gentleman and that you are a lady!

question: Well, consider the source. I don't even know what a lady is.
answer: Exactly! I thought a gentleman was somebody who owned horses. Turns out, the short and very simple definition of a gentleman or a lady is

question: Where did he get all that information?
answer: From the oddest place. His parent's told him. I don't think I got that memo.

question: So now I suppose he's trying to make those two dancers feel as comfortable as possible.
Well...I admit it. I'm glad to hear that.
What?!!
answer: It's true. She swept him out the door whispering little French things into his ear.

question: Oh, no! Not Sophie! No way! Please don't tell me that!!
answer: What are you going to do? Go over to her place and kick in the door?

question: You're goddamn right I am!
Coward!
Come on! Come on, damn it!
Scare me, why don't you?!!? You stupid son of a bitch!!!
What in the hell are you doing here!! You're supposed to be over on San Vicente Boulevard having unsafe sex with that slut Sophie!!
Well, you should be! Thanks to you, my heart is in my neck!
Goodnight!
answer: Eve, if you'll let me, I can --

question: Look! I'm limping! How attractive is that?! What if this is for life?!
Well, you had better!! Wait a minute. There.
answer: Thanks. Steady. Steady. It's going to be all right in no time. I went to Sophie's and she was very hospitable.

question: Is that what you call it?
answer: But it just wasn't where I wanted to be so I left as politely as I could and found a taxi. But I asked the driver to drop me here instead of at the hotel. There's a song Mister Como sings called "On the Street Where You Live." You know it?

question: Sing it to me.
answer: "All at once am I--several stories high-- knowing I'm--on the street-- where you live." It's about a young man who is overjoyed just to be standing in front of the house of the person he loves.

question: Adam...dumb question, but humor me. Have you ever had sex before?
How is that possible?
answer: In 1962, when the bomb was dropped on Los Angeles, my parents were in our fallout shelter. That's where I was born. We only survived because it was a huge shelter as fallout shelters go. My father worked on it secretly for years. When he had to, he used contractors, but always from out-of- state and always for just a portion of the job. He told them it was a secret government experiment done through CalTech. My Dad's not a liar, but he felt in this case he had no choice. Of course, it had to be a secret, because we had just enough supplies to last three people thirty-five years. That's also why I have no brothers or sisters. The air vent was the really tricky part, but he was able to cut into a flood control sewer. What I'd like to do Eve, is take you down into the fallout shelter with me. We could live there with my Mom and Dad. My dad said if I found a healthy girl I should "bring her on down". And you look plenty healthy to me.

question: Uh-huh. Adam?
I want you to go back to the hotel now. I'll call you a cab.
answer: Of course. I shouldn't be over here at this hour.

question: That's right. And I'll see you in the morning in the lobby. Do you mind waiting outside for the taxi?
answer: Not at all. And Eve thank you for tonight...and for the kiss. My first.

question: My pleasure.
answer: It was at least as good as the sky.

question: Really? Okay!
answer: And I think better than the ocean. I'm serious!

question: Goddamn, Adam!
I'm sorry. I took the Lord's name in vain again, didn't I? I'm so sorry.
answer: No! There's an Adult Bookstore back there! I'll be right back!

question: Okay, Troy! Let's get those all-beef frozen patties!
answer: How 'bout we check with Eve first?

question: You bet!
answer: So, did you buy a movie?

question: What?
answer: A magazine? A toy perhaps? In the bookstore.

question: No, I wouldn't go in one of those places with a gas mask on.
answer: I know what you mean! I usually wear a big hat and dark glasses.

question: Does that work?
I'm Nina Aron, Adam.
Very well, thank you. I'm with the County Family Services Department. Eve tells me you've been living in a bomb shelter most of your life.
Adam, I'd like to introduce you to my associate -- Mr. Brown.
We want you to come with us so we can talk some more about your experiences.
My office.
Well, that depends...
answer: I thank you very much for the invitation, but I'm quite busy today. Perhaps I could see you tomorrow.

question: I thank you very much for the invitation, but I'm quite busy today. Perhaps I could see you tomorrow.
answer: Adam....you should go with Dr. Aron. It's the best thing. The best thing for you. I promise.

question: ...All right, Eve. If you say so.
Well what was I supposed to do?! He wants me to live underground with him! That's like Silence of the Lambs, don't you think?!
answer: I know...I know. You did the right thing.

question: Oh, no!
Oh, my God!
answer: He'll catch him. Hi. This is Nina Aron. I've got a run away and I'm going to need police assistance.

question: No! Not the police! Don't call them!
answer: I have to. If a complaint is made and the person resists obser--

question: No, I can't have that! They'll come with their cars and their guns and their handcuffs--
answer: Calm down, please. This man needs help and you need protection from him. That's obvious.

question: You know, I don't think so. I'm confused but you know, I don't think he'd ever hurt me. I don't think he'd hurt anyone.
answer: And now you must let me be the judge of that!

question: I was frightened and I didn't know what to think! But you know-I believe him. I think he just wants to go home. Wherever the hell that is...
answer: Let's all remain calm. That's the key thing.

question: Adam, you really shouldn't try to drive that truck!
Bye, Adam!
answer: And thanks for always being happy!

question: Oh. Well, you're...certainly welcome!
answer: Hey!!! That's my car, you son of a bitch!! Don't ask them! They're as fucked-up as the other guy!

question: Let's all just try to remain calm. That's the key thing.
answer: How 'bout I just knock the shit out of you?!

question: This it? What do you want to do with it?
And if we can't find him?
Hey, Eve? Eve? What's wrong?
answer: I don't know. Everything's so neat. It's all just so...goddamn dear. Damn!

question: See these? Found them in the box with the cards. These are stock certificates. IBM. AT&T. Polaroid. Thanks, Jason. Millions upon millions upon millions! The cards. The stock! The clothes! The toothpaste! The guy was on the level! And you blew it! A man walks into your life who is the kindest, most polite, honest, trustworthy, incredibly rich guy you have ever met in your life!! And what do you do?!
Yeah! That's thinking.
answer: He was always so "nice"! How was I supposed to know that's a good thing?! "Nice" is weird! Nice is...what is "nice"? It's not cool! I'll tell you that. Was it ever?

question: I don't know. I like to think so.
answer: Well, at least I fell for him before I found out he was rich! That's new. Wait a minute! He said today he knew where home was. What happened this morning?! Where did you go?!

question: To get some frozen poultry.
We came back to the house!
No. No, wait a minute. We stopped at a porno store.
An adult bookstore. He was very excited about seeing it. You think home is under a dirty bookstore in the Valley?
Trendy address.
answer: Have you got a basement? Is there a back entrance? Why would you put a fallout shelter under a porno shop?

question: None of this stuff was here in 1962. The Valley was mostly small homes and fruit orchards.
answer: Well, we've come a long way, haven't we? I want to go home.

question: Yes, Mrs. Webber we are. I'm also from Pasadena.
answer: A toast! To Adam and Eve!

question: What is this sh...stuff?!
answer: Hot Dr. Pepper! Most people don't know how good it is heated up.

question: Eve, I've got to go back! My parents can't handle this up here. And there was no bomb, was there?
See! I can't tell them that! I can't ever let them know. It makes their life..well, frankly... a joke. I can't let that happen. You understand?
answer: We can make this work, Adam! Believe me! I'm very good at making things work!

question: My mother's like that.
answer: It took a while to convince Archbishop Milker that Adam wasn't God, and he was pretty broken up about it, too, until I showed him my plans for Los Angeles' hottest and most original night spot. You'll be a ten percent partner and still retain ownership of the entrance.

question: You put the tape in here and you get a movie -- in your own home.
No, Mom, I've turned it into Dad's office.
Eve and I...eloped. We're married.
That's wonderful. We Webber guys have mighty good luck when it comes to women.
answer: It's kind of a combination television- typewriter-telephone-post office type of thing. I'll show it to you later.

question: This is great son, just great. By the way, Eve's last name. Rus-to-kov, that's not Russian, is it?
answer: It's Ukrainian. Her grandparents immigrated here.

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Dad, I don't know how to tell you this. And I was going to wait a while, but I think...Dad,there was no bomb. A plane crashed into our backyard. I looked it up in old newspapers.

question: You're sure?
answer: Positive. The Soviet Union collapsed without a shot being fired. The Cold War is over.

question: That's what everybody believes?
What? Did the politburo just one day say - "We give up?"
answer: Yes. That's kind of how it was.

question: Uh-huh. My gosh, those Commies are brilliant! You've got to hand it to 'em! "No, we didn't drop any bombs! Oh yes, our evil empire has collapsed! Poor, poor us!" I bet they've even asked the West for aid! Right?!
